steps.p: We are speeding on a highway to CO₂ hell…
… and we need to slow down. because it's soon too late.
The red smoke filling up on your left is how much CO₂ we have emitted into the atmosphere since 1850. CO₂ traps heat. The more heat gets trapped, the hotter our planet gets - and this isn't good.
Human activity has been increasing the amount of CO₂ mostly since the industrial revolution in the early 1800s and...
… we are pouring more out and faster than ever before.
We have emitted about 2200 gigatonnes of CO₂ in the atmosphere - the uncertainty around this estimated amount is as much as the smoke you see at the edge.
That much extra CO₂ means that we are already at almost 1 ºC of global warming which is already super bad for our planet.
Where has all that CO₂ come from? Here are some countings:

Although, no matter how you count it and divide it, what we have emitted remains emitted. At the current speed, global warming will reach 1.5 ºC around 2040. When we reach 1.5 ºC we are hitting trouble.
We need to slow this down.

data.p: Historical time series: Global cumulative CO2 emissions including fossil fuels and industry plus land-use change emissions from Global Carbon Project until 2017. Unit change from C toCO2. After 2017 we add a constant annual emissions of 17 Gt CO2
Remaining carbon budget and related uncertainty: as reported in IPCC, 2018: Global Warming of 1.5°C.
Partition of global accumulated emissions 1990-2017: Our World in Data
